page_analysis.text_content:
Setback considerations

Easements
Some easements affect setbacks i.e., setbacks must be measured
from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line as illustrat-
ed in Fig 16 on this page. Easements that affect setbacks are:
• Creek easements
• Public street easements

Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.

Sidewalks
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line. Often, the street ease-
ment or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the
sidewalk. Fig 16 on this page illustrates this common circum-
stance and how the setbacks are affected i.e., they must be mea-
sured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.

Oddly shaped lots
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious.
Fig 17 on page 23 indicates the appropriate site plan for lot shapes
about which questions often arise:
• flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• corner lot (Fig 17 B)
• through lot (Fig 17 D)
• wedge-shaped lot (Fig 17 E)
• lot with more than four sides (Fig 17 F & G)

Flag & substandard lots
Fig 17 on page 23 also illustrates examples of setbacks that have
been reduced for smaller or oddly shaped lots e.g.,
• the front setback of a flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• the street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that
are less than 50' wide (Fig 17 C)

Fig 16 Setbacks: easements and sidewalks

measured from the edge of the public
street easement or right-of-way. (See
section on Lot Size for more information
about public street easements.)

Note: The space between the sidewalk
edge and the lot line is part of the public
right of way. It may be 0' or more than
15'. Please ask at the Development
Center.

Note: For informa-
tion regarding creek
easements, contact
the Santa Clara Valley
Water District

visual_elements.description: A diagram titled 'Fig 16 Setbacks: easements and sidewalks' illustrating a property lot with various setback considerations. It shows a 'Buildable area' in the center, surrounded by a 'Rear yard', 'Front yard', and two 'Interior-side yard' areas. An 'Easement' is depicted at the top, extending beyond the rear yard. A 'Creek or public access easement e.g., street or alley' is indicated next to the easement. A 'Sidewalk' is shown at the bottom, in front of the 'Front yard'. Arrows indicate measurement directions for setbacks. Callouts explain that setbacks are measured from the easement regardless of lot lines, and from lot lines regardless of sidewalks. A key defines symbols for 'Curb', 'Lot line', 'Sidewalk', 'Required setbacks', 'Buildable area', and 'Easement'.
A grey box with white text providing a note: 'For information regarding creek easements, contact the Santa Clara Valley Water District'.

The hyphen in '-middle of the street' appears to be a line break artifact or a formatting issue.

qualifiers.text: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line.
Often, the street easement or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the sidewalk.
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious.
if the lot line is in the middle of the street
The space between the sidewalk edge and the lot line is part of the public right of way.
substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide

conditions.text: setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line
setbacks are affected i.e., they must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.
the setback is measured from the edge of the public street easement or right-of-way.
It may be 0' or more than 15'.
the street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide

logical_relationships.expression: IF Some easements affect setbacks THEN setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line

IF The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line AND Often, the street easement or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the sidewalk THEN setbacks are affected i.e., they must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.
IF the lot line is in the middle of the street THEN the setback is measured from the edge of the public street easement or right-of-way.
IF The space between the sidewalk edge and the lot line is part of the public right of way THEN It may be 0' or more than 15'.

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if an easement affects setbacks.
If an easement affects setbacks, measure setbacks from the edge of the easement.
Note that most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.
Evaluate if the sidewalk indicates the lot line or if a street easement/public right-of-way extends beyond the sidewalk.
If conditions in step 4 are met, measure setbacks from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.
If the lot line is in the middle of the street, measure the setback from the edge of the public street easement or right-of-way.
Consider the space between the sidewalk edge and the lot line as part of the public right of way.
Determine if the space between the sidewalk edge and lot line is 0' or more than 15'.
For substandard corner lots less than 50' wide, apply reduced street-side yard setback.
